snippet.textDisplay:
Personally, I think there was too much weight in the back of the chopper,
I would say 1200 pounds maybe a little more. When the pilot tried to go
Above the foggy overcast, it stalled the engines because of the weight,
And it had nowhere to go but down...killing everyone on board. A tragedy
That should have never happened. They should have rented two choppers
Instead of one. Hopefully this will never happen again.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: The Pilot made a descending 90 degree turn and flew into that Canyon in that fog and crashed into that hill at an elevation of 1085 feet. By the appearance of that thick fog, he must have been disoriented and possibly stalled the aircraft in that turn, lost lift, and fell out of the sky. Speculation on my part. We will have to wait for the investigation to find out if there was an equipment failure or if it was just pilot error.
snippet.textOriginal: The Pilot made a descending 90 degree turn and flew into that Canyon in that fog and crashed into that hill at an elevation of 1085 feet. By the appearance of that thick fog, he must have been disoriented and possibly stalled the aircraft in that turn, lost lift, and fell out of the sky. Speculation on my part. We will have to wait for the investigation to find out if there was an equipment failure or if it was just pilot error.

snippet.textDisplay: Sadly, he couldnt file IFR on the ground before departure unfortunately because of OPSPEC limitations.. even though he was instrument rated. The company's OPSPECs didnt allow IFR flight.. only VFR. What he should have done once he entered the soup is start climbing, declare an emergency with SOCAL TRACON and pick up pop-up IFR to CMA since thats where they were going in the first place. Who cares if you get interviewed by the FAA on the ground because  you screwed up.... at least you would still be alive and so would all the other occupants onboard.
snippet.textOriginal: Sadly, he couldnt file IFR on the ground before departure unfortunately because of OPSPEC limitations.. even though he was instrument rated. The company's OPSPECs didnt allow IFR flight.. only VFR. What he should have done once he entered the soup is start climbing, declare an emergency with SOCAL TRACON and pick up pop-up IFR to CMA since thats where they were going in the first place. Who cares if you get interviewed by the FAA on the ground because  you screwed up.... at least you would still be alive and so would all the other occupants onboard.

snippet.textDisplay: Fog did not cause the crash. This is a misleading report. Eye witness said that he heard huge booming sound and after few seconds, he saw the fireball on the hills. It indicates that something happened before the helicopter plunged from 2300 ft height, which was well above the height of the hills there.  The crash is either due to mechanical malfunction or planned assassination.
snippet.textOriginal: Fog did not cause the crash. This is a misleading report. Eye witness said that he heard huge booming sound and after few seconds, he saw the fireball on the hills. snippet.textDisplay: I have been trying to tell anyone who will listen that the last communication between the pilot and the air traffic controller was not heard by the pilot of the helicopter because he misunderstood the frequency that the prior controller told he to change to and that was 134.2 he repeated back "34.2" instead! snippet.textDisplay: My opinion is that pilot complacency and ego were the major contributors. In such thick cloud cover and fog conditions, he should have told them to drive there instead. It was a Sunday afternoon and traffic would not have been very congested. Instead, he probably decided that he could easily make the flight since he had done it so many times before. He lost his bearings, got confused, likely got frustrated, and flew into the mountain by accident. It is entirely possible that some on board might have been growing impatient; especially considering the delay outside Burbank and may have pressured the pilot to hurry up. This is all speculation obviously, but I can see it making sense.
snippet.textOriginal: My opinion is that pilot complacency and ego were the major contributors. In such thick cloud cover and fog conditions, he should have told them to drive there instead. It was a Sunday afternoon and traffic would not have been very congested. Instead, he probably decided that he could easily make the flight since he had done it so many times before. He lost his bearings, got confused, likely got frustrated, and flew into the mountain by accident. It is entirely possible that some on board might have been growing impatient; especially considering the delay outside Burbank and may have pressured the pilot to hurry up. This is all speculation obviously, but I can see it making sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is so sad for all families involved. Sounds like the pilot was disoriented at the end. He got stuck in clouds and heard the atc say he was still too low for flight following. He had spatial disorientation so he was trying to turn around to get out of the clouds and was disoriented and didn't realize how close he was to the mountain. Before he could correct it was too late. It was an accident. Pilot error yes but a total accident.
I have been reading everything about this incident because its saddens me. I realized I need to stop speculating as it isn't changing the situation. Prayers to the Bryant family. 🙏❤
snippet.textOriginal:
This is so sad for all families involved. Sounds like the pilot was disoriented at the end. He got stuck in clouds and heard the atc say he was still too low for flight following. He had spatial disorientation so he was trying to turn around to get out of the clouds and was disoriented and didn't realize how close he was to the mountain. Before he could correct it was too late. It was an accident. Pilot error yes but a total accident. 
I have been reading everything about this incident because its saddens me. I realized I need to stop speculating as it isn't changing the situation. Prayers to the Bryant family. 🙏❤

snippet.textDisplay: Perhaps the pilot thought he had done a full 180 degree turn at the end so he could head back to the less mountainous valley of the 101, but having switched from VFR to IFR, had instead turned westbound toward the mountains. The high rate of speed could be attributed to 1) He was falsely confident he'd be over the valley once he got below the cloud ceiling, and 2) Get-there-itis. He felt pressured and rushed. They'd already held a hovering pattern for 12 minutes before entering Van Nuys airspace, and now they were backtracking (possibly back to John Wayne airport), and a very famous customer and his crew would be disappointed.
snippet.textOriginal: Perhaps the pilot thought he had done a full 180 degree turn at the end so he could head back to the less mountainous valley of the 101, but having switched from VFR to IFR, had instead turned westbound toward the mountains. The high rate of speed could be attributed to 1) He was falsely confident he'd be over the valley once he got below the cloud ceiling, and 2) Get-there-itis. He felt pressured and rushed. They'd already held a hovering pattern for 12 minutes before entering Van Nuys airspace, and now they were backtracking (possibly back to John Wayne airport), and a very famous customer and his crew would be disappointed.

snippet.textDisplay: As I heard all of the witness statements and the statements made by the NTSB I started to do research on my own, I’ve read almost any article available, along with all video from pilots and professionals, kind of came weirdly obsessed with this situation and the more I read and watch a lot of the things don’t match together. I’m not a conspiracy theory person, I believe they died and don’t believe any of the conspiracy things going around at all. I’m just pointing out how far apart everyone reporting on this is with eachother. Witness claims the helicopter was almost at a hover only 3-5mph (remind you he is a audio engineer) only a few hundred feet off the ground, this correlates with the nearby house doorbell recordings. It sounds like the aircraft is literally right above the houses. Witness said it took somewhere around 20sec for the helicopter to get from where he was to the crash site. Which is only about 1500ft. But the NTSB claims he was above 2,000ft and crashed at 176mph. If it was going that fast it wouldn’t take 20sec to go 1500ft it would’ve been much sooner than that (176mph is equal to 257ft per second which would tell us the aircraft would’ve made impact with the hill in just under 6 seconds from where the witnesses were) and if it was that high it wouldn’t have been so loud like on the audio of the door bell recordings. I’m curious to see what the final verdict of this situation comes out as, it very well will be wrong because in the end it’s going to be a guess in my opinion based on the fact there was no black box or data recording on the aircraft. Sad situation and RIP to everyone involved. I will continue to do my amateur research though!
snippet.textOriginal: As I heard all of the witness statements and the statements made by the NTSB I started to do research on my own, I’ve read almost any article available, along with all video from pilots and professionals, kind of came weirdly obsessed with this situation and the more I read and watch a lot of the things don’t match together. I’m not a conspiracy theory person, I believe they died and don’t believe any of the conspiracy things going around at all. I’m just pointing out how far apart everyone reporting on this is with eachother. Witness claims the helicopter was almost at a hover only 3-5mph (remind you he is a audio engineer) only a few hundred feet off the ground, this correlates with the nearby house doorbell recordings. It sounds like the aircraft is literally right above the houses. Witness said it took somewhere around 20sec for the helicopter to get from where he was to the crash site. Which is only about 1500ft. But the NTSB claims he was above 2,000ft and crashed at 176mph. If it was going that fast it wouldn’t take 20sec to go 1500ft it would’ve been much sooner than that (176mph is equal to 257ft per second which would tell us the aircraft would’ve made impact with the hill in just under 6 seconds from where the witnesses were) and if it was that high it wouldn’t have been so loud like on the audio of the door bell recordings. I’m curious to see what the final verdict of this situation comes out as, it very well will be wrong because in the end it’s going to be a guess in my opinion based on the fact there was no black box or data recording on the aircraft. Sad situation and RIP to everyone involved. I will continue to do my amateur research though!

snippet.textDisplay:
A few precautionary measures could have been taken to possibly prevent this, even if flying in less than ideal conditions.
1. Have a pilot AND copilot on every flight. If there was a copilot in the front seat along with the pilot, there would have been another qualified person there to discover an anomaly or error in judgement that the pilot-in-command may have overlooked, and correct him/her accordingly. Furthermore, if the pilot becomes incapacitated for any reason, there is another person there to take over. Added safety and security. If I had the $$ that Kobe had, without a doubt I would have insisted on this - Two qualified pilots at all times.
2. Always ensure that the aircraft has the latest/greatest avionics on board and in working order prior to any flight carrying passengers. From my understanding, the helicopter did not have a "black box", nor did it have a terrain awareness and warning system. The latter alone may have prevented the accident. Celebrities probably have no clue about the aircraft they own other than its an airplane or helicopter. Take ownership of the aircraft and understand what that aircraft has and what it doesn't have, including its avionics, and the basic workings of those systems.

Although an official NTSB ruling of the cause of the accident has not been announced yet, and probably won't for some time, by all indications it appears that the accident was caused by pilot error. Still, the proper precautionary measures taken as stated, probably would have prevented the accident in my opinion. Too bad.
snippet.textOriginal:
A few precautionary measures could have been taken to possibly prevent this, even if flying in less than ideal conditions.  
1.  Have a pilot AND copilot on every flight.  If there was a copilot in the front seat along with the pilot, there would have been another qualified person there to discover an anomaly or error in judgement that the pilot-in-command may have overlooked, and correct him/her accordingly.  Furthermore, if the pilot becomes incapacitated for any reason, there is another person there to take over.  Added safety and security.   If I had the $$ that Kobe had, without a doubt I would have insisted on this - Two qualified pilots at all times.
2.  Always ensure that the aircraft has the latest/greatest avionics on board and in working order prior to any flight carrying passengers.  From my understanding, the helicopter did not have a "black box", nor did it have a terrain awareness and warning system.  The latter alone may have prevented the accident.  Celebrities probably have no clue about the aircraft they own other than its an airplane or helicopter.  Take ownership of the aircraft and understand what that aircraft has and what it doesn't have, including its avionics,  and the basic workings of those systems.  

Although an official NTSB ruling of the cause of the accident has not been announced yet, and probably won't for some time, by all indications it appears that the accident was caused by pilot error.  Still, the proper precautionary measures taken as stated, probably would have prevented the accident in my opinion.  Too bad.

snippet.textDisplay: The cause of the crash is that the pilot flew into a mountain. Whats so hard to understand? There was serious low level cloud cover on that day and the pilot lost bearing so he tried to regain his bearing by turning around and getting below the clouds but the ground was rising and he misjudged the situation. period.  Not an accident or engine malfunction but simple pilot error. Why is this not being discussed?

snippet.textDisplay:
2:40 "Bryant's pilot had requested Flight Following, where controllers track an aircraft to help the pilot during rough conditions."

This is incorrect and NOT the purpose of Flight Following. The purpose of Flight Following is so ATC Controllers can issue RADAR TRAFFIC information to pilots about other aircraft in their area. They (ATC Controllers) can not see clouds, mountains etc.
snippet.textOriginal:
2:40  "Bryant's pilot had requested Flight Following, where controllers track an aircraft to help the pilot during rough conditions."

This is incorrect and NOT the purpose of Flight Following. The purpose of Flight Following is so ATC Controllers can issue RADAR TRAFFIC information to pilots about other aircraft in their area.  They (ATC Controllers) can not see clouds, mountains etc.

snippet.textDisplay: I was on a small turboprop plane around 10 years ago and the plane was so rocky and shook so uncontrollably that I developed an intense fear of small air craft. The plane dropped 10-20 ft in the air and bounced around so violently and at that moment, I thought I was going to crash and die. Since then, I made it a habit of only flying in commercial Jet air craft, and I will avoid any small planes that are non-commercial or any helicopters. Perhaps it is an irrational fear, but I've known too many people who died in these small aircraft crashes that would have never happened if they flew on commercial jet planes. That being said, I am a huge Kobe fan and my heart is so heavy with this news, and I feel terrible for his family and loved ones.
snippet.textOriginal: I was on a small turboprop plane around 10 years ago and the plane was so rocky and shook so uncontrollably that I developed an intense fear of small air craft. The plane dropped 10-20 ft in the air and bounced around so violently and at that moment, I thought I was going to crash and die. Since then, I made it a habit of only flying in commercial Jet air craft, and I will avoid any small planes that are non-commercial or any helicopters. Perhaps it is an irrational fear, but I've known too many people who died in these small aircraft crashes that would have never happened if they flew on commercial jet planes. That being said, I am a huge Kobe fan and my heart is so heavy with this news, and I feel terrible for his family and loved ones.

snippet.textDisplay: before the turn he was flying low and slow with a low ceiling.  Too low for flight following. Sounds like maybe he was scud running then he completely lost visuals and tried to climb out of it.  Then it appears he flew into the cloud ceiling and became disoriented. A sudden VFR to IMC switch that he wasn’t prepared for, and probably was rusty on. Just because he was IFR certified doesn’t mean he was practicing IFR or current.  Plus add the stress of a high profile client, kids, etc. Plus No Terrain awareness system and no copilot. Big recipe for disaster.
snippet.textOriginal: before the turn he was flying low and slow with a low ceiling.  Too low for flight following. Sounds like maybe he was scud running then he completely lost visuals and tried to climb out of it.  Then it appears he flew into the cloud ceiling and became disoriented. A sudden VFR to IMC switch that he wasn’t prepared for, and probably was rusty on. Just because he was IFR certified doesn’t mean he was practicing IFR or current.  Plus add the stress of a high profile client, kids, etc. Plus No Terrain awareness system and no copilot. Big recipe for disaster.

snippet.textDisplay: This is a premature piece.  The last minute of the helicopter had been following a main road, Las Virgenes Rd., south from 101.  The sudden descent to impact was oblique to that road, at a point at least a mile south of 101.  Along that final road, no significant ground level changes were present; that road follows essentially the same elevation contour in that region; no narrow passes or road cuts are involved.  The crash site was at least 300 feet below  adjacent ridgelines, and high-speed descent to impact was indicated.  Impact location does not imply a level flight into a steep slope.  Whatever happened, it's more possible that sudden loss of flight control above Las Virgenes Road, bordered by buildings, that the desperate pilot was able to turn the descent away from possible ground casualties.  The crash site is in an open area about a quarter-mile east of that road, well clear of the local water district complex.  An attempt to clear any high ground is not implied by spatial details.

snippet.textDisplay: The weather was really weird that day. I've only been is LA for about 6 months off and on this year . But I've never seen it so hazy and foggy like it was that day.
snippet.textOriginal: The weather was really weird that day. I've only been is LA for about 6 months off and on this year . But I've never seen it so hazy and foggy like it was that day.
